Nearly everyone has a great respect for philosophy, as if it was something superior, and that the philosophers are really "wise" men, and possessed real wisdom, while in reality, they are only what the word "philosopher" means - the "lover of wisdom", and anyone who loves "wisdom" , can be called a philosopher!
The truth is, that, while the writings of Cicero, Seneca , Aurelius and others are pleasurable to read, admiring their astonishing way of thinking, in reality, all that philosophical thinking is completely useless and pointless.
That's why Socrates, the wisest of the wise, was so great, by facing and admitting the truth, saying: - "I know that I know nothing"!
In another way, Solomon has said the same at the beginning of the Book of Ecclesiastes: - "Life is useless, all is useless. It is all vanity and in vain...".
The same has said Schopenhauer: -- "The vanity of existence is revealed in the whole form existence assumes: - in the infinity of time and space, contrasted with finiteness of the individual in both... Time and that perishability of all things existing in time...the will to live...reveal the vanity of its striving. Time is that by virtue of which everything becomes nothingness in our hands and loses all real value"....
--- Would you see any sense to take the wise advice of philosophers, on how to live to have a happy life, to the inmates on the death row, which already lost ALL appeals, and their execution is absolutely inevitable?
All of us are on the same situation, are we not?

I graduated in May of 2018 with my BS in Finance and a 3.96 GPA along with 5 honors at the top 3% of my class....and have been unemployed ever since. Without knowing it, I've spent much of my time asking philosophical questions and frustrated at the lack of answers. I've also spent time watching every. single. Crash Course. video. It really helped me round out my education, as business school tends to be exceptionally myopic.

This was my last one, and it helped more than you know. It helped me to come to terms with the realization that I adore my field of finance, and just because I can't find a place within it right now doesn't mean I'm worthless. You start to think that when 97% of your class is employed and you, the one with all the honors, aren't.



By extension of my love of finance, I've developed spreadsheets and budgets that are all ready and waiting to calculate the most efficient deployment of my capital (salary)...but I have none. I spend my days at home, and speak to nobody but my parents. Not because I'm antisocial (far from it!), but because I'm A. completely broke and B. undergoing a transition of friendship.


This course has helped me to realize that the people I met at community college ten years ago are not lifelong friends. Back when I was a hippie stoner and held a GPA of 1.02 along with multiple arrests, they fit that time of my life where I liked to be a party monster. Having never gone to high school, I was completely unprepared for college in any way. I was getting a wild rebellious streak out of my system that took four years, but it wasn't truly my identity. As they say, it was just a phase.


Unfortunately, due to my life choices and path, I don't know anyone else. The friends I used to have at community college I now see were just stoner buddies who went nowhere since I left. Almost nobody graduated besides me, and certainly none went on to actual college. To quote the quite literal only friend I still have, "You ever stop smoking weed with people...and realize that was all you had in common?". Yeah, I have, and it was. They fit that time of my life when I needed to be wild and out there.


But now they're all trying to make a go of what I call the "nesting instinct" and either settling down or just not growing up in my view. So, here I sit, at the end of the last Crash Course video, still unemployed, still with questions, still having let go of so many pseudo-friends with none to replace them.

But for the first time, I feel happy.

Sometimes the best philosopher is the one who stops asking questions.  I believe that Sisyphus did not create the boulder, but he CHOOSE to role the boulder. The boulder is the questions we work so hard to answer only to questions the answer when we have them. To be human is to ask questions, even when there are no answers. Philosophy is fun. It can make you happy, but it can also drive you crazy in a never ending spiral of doubt that makes you question your own sanity. I am proudly able to say I don't need to know, and I know longer care. For thousands of years people have tried to answer these questions, I am not going to be the one to do it nor do I need to. In the end nobody every really leaves this place with any answers, life is not a question to be answered it is a reality to experience. The questions are only questions in our minds. Every single philosophical debate boils down to people arguing over which team they like better. The meaning of life is just to live life. I am putting this boulder down for a bit. Finally I am happy with expecting what I don't know.  Laozi once said, a bowl is most useful when it is empty. I get what that means now.

After becoming atheist, I, inevitably, reached the point of nihilism. Thankfully, I had previously read about Camus' Absurdism. And life became all about that little girl. Nothing else matters. It really is all about reproducing and survival. But I also discovered that there's something beautiful about the fact that I can do everything in my power to shield her from suffering. To make sure she has a good teacher and to make sure she has all the chances she needs to give her own life meaning. So, with reproduction and survival, I'd also like to add reducing suffering and increasing happiness in myself and others.

I always ask questions regarding reality, existence, God, constantly searching ideas till I got agnostic then back to theistic.... I tried to understand and build unity among beliefs, misconceptions, and raises questions on society like corruption, death penalty, ideal society, relationships, and different practices...... I begun to study history and appreciated it much, I also love arts, music, theater, and writing.......I also valued the beauty of math and the wonders of physics............ I did all of those even before this series of Crash Course started last year when I was totally depressed and with anxiety disorder which made me stopped schooling.....depression, anxiety, stress, and my experience of not getting in school even added my questions about my life and humanity...... Now, I am more open minded, I learn to listen to different opinions and respect them, I begun to be more reasonable, to build consensus and agreements than disagreements, I am more of a pacifier and peace maker now...... I try to see similarities than dividing ideas....with sometimes getting headaches and insomnias with just thinking about deep questions.... I am interested in the Fine Arts and Education right now, but living like a philosopher is an unending work of questions.....changing perspectives..... challenging ideas...... ridding some old beliefs...and withholding other beliefs...... and most of the time looking out in the blue skies, daydreaming, and being too silent while deeply thinking of a philosophical question....... I am introverted....that's why maybe arts and philosophy are my hobbies and interests.... side from that according to a lot of Multiple Intelligences tests I answered and got... I always get Visual-Spatial, Musical, Interpersonal, and Existential (the new 9th intelligence) intelligences in my top lists. just sharing. :D Farewell Crash Course Philosophy........................ time to venture Mythology. :'( I'll miss this. I feel like the God, or a god, or any being of some kind, possibly still humanoid, may have created the universe just to watch it, to enjoy it, or learn from it. Just the same as when we humans create simulations for ourselves, like Conway's Game of Life. In conway's game of life, you can start a board in a scenario and let it simulate, and it's interesting to which cells live, and which die. If they all lived, the board would do nothing worth creating the simulation for. Without evil, death risk, or uncertainty being a part of what has to happen for or world to continue operating, there would be nothing to learn from, or simply be entertained by it.
This does not solve that the god may not be All-Knowing, or All-Good, but that's probably because I'm comparing his relationship with humans, to humans' relationship with objects in a simulation.
I'm not going to pass this off as a fully clear-cut, satisfactory, or comforting answer, but it makes the most sense to me until I'm satisfied with another answer.
Everyone reading this, you do not have to agree with this. This is just what I think, and I respect you all. ^u^

As to the Existentialist POV presented here: 1.) Are our values really voluntary or (either through nature or nurture) innate? If they are plastic, they must be at least very difficult to change, and probably (i.e. at least apparently) more difficult for some than others - so as a whole, must we not think of values as generally immutable? 2.) Some people will obviously have more or less ability to seek out and strive for what they place value in, but (baring possibly some kind of mental disorder, and I could see debate even in that case) everyone wants to do what they see as valuable, to live their values - because it gives you happiness, or contentment, or satisfaction - or any other word for pleasure. Therefore Existentialism = Hedonism and vice versa.
As a matter of fact Hedonism could be seen as the motivating factor behind all known biological life and understanding, and the thus the root of all characterized philosophy. The only usual argument over our root motivation, to increase pleasure and/or reduce pain (as if there's any difference between them) is the erroneous argument that Hedonism somehow seduces people into irrationally seeking some kind(s) of overdose of immediate pleasure(s) with total disregard for all obvious, painful consequences of doing so. We all obviously and constantly budget our pain vs. pleasure over time. I often use the term 'Practical Hedonism' to get this point across succinctly, but in reality that caveat is redundant and unnecessary. Hedonism also does not rule out altruism since most of us see value in helping others in their pleasure vs. pain - thus making us feel good - plus the additional practicality of helping the group to help ourselves (even for the more self centered. Argued exceptions for sadists and the like would be encapsulated within the exception of mental disorders mentioned above.) Obviously some, like young children, require assistance in budgeting their pain vs. pleasure. (Halloween candy binges and tummy aches being a relatively safe primary lesson for many.)
The only exceptions to this Hedonistic root motivation in practice (that I can see) would be either concepts of duty/honor and/or religion, which are merely means of control. Concepts of duty or honor are based on social acceptance. When viewed as such, we can not only see it as differing among social groups, but can make our own determinations as to the value of the approval of a certain, limited social group versus the level of our own potential pleasure or suffering. As to the religious exception, it isn't really 'religion' as a concept, but merely certain small groups of religious sects who encourage the idea of some afterlife that will reward wasting your life in misery for the promise of over-matching pleasure after death. Without any verifiable evidence ever in history, this concept must be indoctrinated during one's childhood development. While, yes, there are some cases of those raised atheist/agnostic later in life being converted into a religious group, these usually follow regular patterns: either a period of emotional pain (whether merely unfulfillment, or in whatever form) and the promise of the religion as a solution to eventually replace the pain with pleasure; or due to the social pressure of a loved one (as in marriage.) This can be easily born out by considering the consequence of waiting until one reached an age capable of considered reason before introducing the concepts of religion or afterlife. Such concepts would almost certainly be seen as ludicrous by most. However, the only advantage to a religious upbringing, outside of social acceptance, is to keep people in a state of acceptance of pain rather than demanding their share of readily available pleasure. Thus religions that promote concepts like heaven, reincarnation, mortification of the flesh, etc. can be seen as not only a means of control, but innately immoral - i.e. in opposition to our evolved Hedonism and Existential self-actualization. The religious indoctrination of vulnerable children would have to also be considered abuse.
While this is merely a progression of logical thought (and an extremely abbreviated version of arguments due to the format here) in our present heavily indoctrinated and controlled society, they would probably be considered radical to most.
I'm no great philosopher, claim only mediocre intelligence, and try my best to keep an open mind. My propositions here are more a result of observations throughout my life than anything read or taught. I encourage any constructive counter arguments that could increase my conception, understanding, or personal pleasure overall. (However those offended or incensed, please spare me angry rhetoric.)

One thought I had while watching this final video is that the worth of my life can be determined by how it has affected those of other people. In general have I reduced the suffering of others or increased it? Without strictly keeping tabs I think of my life in terms of payments of my own effort and withdrawals from the efforts of those around me. A simple example is driving. If another driver makes an error and I take action to prevent suffering (a payment), I immediately remind myself of a time I made a mistake driving and another other driver's skill prevented suffering I may have caused (a withdrawal). I try to have as many of the former events as I can and as few of the latter. Of course I know nothing at all about the full consequences my actions. Allowing a poor driver to continue without incident may condemn them to causing worse suffering at a later date. I can only judge the odds of this eventuality and try to make good bets. And no, saving a life would not entitle me to take one (it occurs to me this would make a good movie plot about a repentant assassin) because I cannot calculate the worth of another's life. Intentionally causing the death of another could only be 'repaid' by my own.

Now -- how to go about repaying the debt created by enjoying this video series?

About the topic of the video :
I think that as in many cases - people confuse two different things as the same thing. We are actually asked many questions, and a final comparing question. we are asked "how does a good life look - viewed from person x's perspective", and "how does a good life look - viewed from your perspective", and which perspective is correct. but remember - GOOD is relativistic by its nature, so asking about "which one of different perspectives of good - is correct", is not valid.

Good is a value given by a cause to work for or against. Different people value different causes, so a "goodness" of a thing depends on the person that we ask.

For conclusion, if someone thinks that his or someone's(and the opposite) life is good/bad - they are both correct.

Do I know what a good life is?

I am REASONABLY SURE I do
It is to have our biological/evolutionary needs met. Those for social relations as much as for subsistence. In this sense, Aristotle is right, there is a human essence, a mode of life that offers the best possible habitat for humans. It`s just that his vision was wrong.

What I DON`T know is how individuals with unique packages of frustrated needs can best compensate for these frustrations. In this sense, Camus and the existentialists are right, we all have to make our own choices as to what makes our lives meaningful.

What I AM TOTALLY SURE I KNOW, is how somebody with a good life will behave. He will choose to keep on living for as long as possible, no matter how much he complains about things.

A few comments about this video:
1. How can Camus even suggest Sisyphus was happy? The tale is about an extreneous but futile task. Enjoying the fruits of one's labour is what gives, in our mind, meaning to our efforts, something Sisyphus is clearly denied due to never achieving his goals.
2. Nozick's experience machine is a clear equivalent to the demon suggested by DeCartes, and as this solipsistic hypothesis really isn't disproven, asking oneself whether it is worthwhile to be inside one cannot answer about a life worth living, for AFAWK that could very well be our life. In any case, impact upon our world can still be achieved even inside the experience machine, the fact that this world is a figment of the imagination should not change that.

I would say that I am more of a hedonist, in that I live my life for pleasure, as opposed to my parents, who largely lived to accomplish life goals that they had (career-wise, getting married/having kids, etc.). However, I would also say that I live with rational self-interest, in that I do not go to extremes with pleasure seeking (in a way that hurts others, or even myself to a certain point), and I also take into account minimizing displeasure.
For instance, if I was not rational in my self-interest, I would lie to people when it made my life easier, and would have cheated on my past girlfriends; however, I know that doing so would hurt others, and also cause me a headache/drama/distrust in the long run. Rationally, the payoff for lying to people or cheating on a girlfriend wasn't worth the cost of displeasure it would have caused me.
I would also say that, in estimating what constitutes a good life for me, being well-informed about matters of substance also qualifies as a quality to be desired. My parents went to college to get their degrees as a matter of attaining a life goal; my mom, for interest, is pursuing her doctorate, and is currently the head of the nursing department at the vocational school at which she teaches. However, she is woefully ill-informed about world history, foreign policy, domestic policy, physics/chemistry, etc. She knows medicine/surgery, and that is about it. When confronted with the fact that she is ill-informed about a subject upon which she is speaking, she will say things something to the effect of "I don't want to think about it". In contrast, I am always wanting to learn about matters of importance, and pursue knowledge independent of attaining some degree or life-goal... learning is the goal. I not only attend college in order to help with my career, I also take classes that are not related to my degrees, and will continue taking classes in different fields after I reach my doctorate; I spend much of my free time trying to learn about the world and the people on it. I think that would also be important when determining if I have had a good life- a pursuit of knowledge.
To be honest, I feel like my life was a waste. I'm 35 years old now and just 3 years ago, I have finally decided what I was going to do with it.

Just wanted to say I thought you all did well in this series but, I am surprised that Hegel didn't get mentioned throughout the entirety of the series. He brought an interesting perspective to philosophy saying that philosophy is a subset of history which is the opposite of some philosophers. To me that raises some important questions about philosophy.  Should philosophers be historians in order to understand the context of philosophy or is that context irrelevant to the whole of philosophy? Does philosophy create a paradigm to view history or does history affect the perspective in which that paradigm was created?  This to me is one of the most fascinating questions in philosophy.

Loved CC:Philosophy, and it's because of this that i ask: aren't you ending this series with an unjustified assumption? Is a life that contains philosophical inquiry indeed automatically better than a life that is satisfied with the surface of things?

In other words, if you found out through eating it that the only fruit on the philosophical-inquiry tree is cognitive dissonance, would you keep eating? Why would you? Would you even allow the tree to exist or others to eat from it?

What if, through strict logical reasoning and philosophical inquiry, one reaches the conclusion that knowledge in the end is actually harmful to the well being of humans? Would you be able to accept obscurantism to be the highest achievement and direct outcome of philosophy?

Also: you must construct additional p̶y̶l̶o̶n̶s̶ nietzsches :)

I started to dread your videos later on in this series... It felt more like a pulpit to provide an exposé on whatever it was that was in need to preach. Often times raising things that would never be explored so that you could devote more time to something I found troublingly problematic. To have abandoned any honest pursuit of truth, in favor of claiming an unearned authority. When I saw this new video, I had primed myself to watch something that I knew I may not enjoy. I was wrong. This video was a return to the early Crash Course Philosophy that I enjoyed tremendously.

Please do not mistake this for me not liking philosophy being provided that I do not agree with, but rather see this as a dislike for being told asserted truths. Where there is question, or description, there is the beginning of understanding. Where there is a truth told to be ingested, the experience becomes vapid.

I have to make a clarification: this video, right at the beginning consider Camus to be an Existentialist, and yes, while he did converse and associate with many existentialists, it should be noted that he was an Absurdist. It may seem like a minor nit-pick; however, in consideration of Philosophical Schools, it would seem that Existentialism focuses on a Modernist idea that we can create meaning in our life while Absurdism focuses on the opposite, that we have no meaning whatsoever. Therefore, we must simply be happy with ourselves and what we can do.

Many of the ancient Greek Hellenistic schools would also oppose The Experience Machine. They were opposed to the Hedonists in that they believed that pleasure was not what was important for a good life, though they disagreed on whether it was preferable or not. The different schools are all pretty interesting, but the one I find particularly fascinating is Epicureanism, which was the first one to focus on materialism and is what Karl Marx wrote his dissertation on.

In terms of the good life they believed the absence of pain was the greatest pleasure you could have and that we should live in accordance with nature, which is fairly admirable in many ways. It's their metaphysics that's most interesting about them though. They were atomists that believed everything could be explained by physical causes, namely the random interactions of atoms, leading them to adopt a deterministic world view. This also meant that they believed that if there were any divine beings they were absent ones, detached from the world and therefore not really worth worrying about, which links back to the good life. One of Epicurus' main concerns was teaching others how best to achieve that blissful state of painlessness, and not worrying about gods is part of that. He also had reasons for not worrying about death, ones that are still worth thinking about nowadays. If any of that sounds interesting to people I highly recommend they look into Epicurus and Epicureanism, it's definitely worthwhile.

Anyway, thank you to everyone at Crash Course Philosophy for reigniting my passion for philosophy, you all did a fantastic job!
